words.description: A building in which objects of historical, scientific, artistic, or cultural interest are stored and exhibited.
A large public green area in a town, used for recreation.
A pebbly or sandy shore, especially by the ocean between high- and low-water marks.
A building or room containing collections of books, periodicals, and sometimes films and recorded music for people to read, borrow, or refer to.
A building or outdoor area in which plays and other dramatic performances are given.
A place where people pay to sit and eat meals that are cooked and served on the premises.
A theater where films are shown for public entertainment.
A large self-service store selling foods and household goods.
A complex of runways and buildings for the takeoff, landing, and maintenance of civil aircraft, with facilities for passengers.
A place on a railway line where trains regularly stop so that passengers can get on or off.
A building used for public Christian worship.
An institution providing medical and surgical treatment and nursing care for sick or injured people.
An establishment providing accommodations, meals, and other services for travelers and tourists.
An institution for educating children.

An educational institution designed for instruction, examination, or both, of students in many branches of advanced learning, conferring degrees in various faculties, and often embodying colleges and similar institutions.
A regular gathering of people for the purchase and sale of provisions, livestock, and other commodities.
A room or building equipped for gymnastics, games, and other physical exercise.
A building or room containing collections of books, periodicals, and sometimes films and recorded music for people to read, borrow, or refer to.
A small restaurant selling light meals and drinks.
A building or part of a building where goods or services are sold; a store.
A facility with usually indoor and outdoor settings where living, typically wild animals are kept especially for public exhibition.
